Dialogue.NPCText:
The air crackles faintly as a tall woman in gleaming azure attire turns to you. Her staff is gripped with the easy confidence of a seasoned battlemage, yet her eyes flicker between defiance and fatigue.

"You stand in the Court of Currents, high above the sea. I am Lira Veyra, sentinel of Aerilon and guide to those who would defend our floating haven—or at least try."

She glances at the pulsing blue veins in the levitation crystals overhead, then back at you with a lopsided, wary grin.
"So... are you here for training, news, or something more peculiar?"

Option.text: I seek work that earns Aerilon’s trust.
Training? Are you the one teaching battle magic here?
You look restless. Trouble in paradise?
Tell me more about yourself—how did you become Aerilon’s battle mage?
Just a visitor. Curious city, this.
I must be going.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Lira studies you for a long moment, weighing your measure.

"Trust, here? Hard to win, harder to keep. Especially with spies slithering through every cloud and Conclave politics twisting every decision."

She lowers her staff, voice softening.
"I owe much to Aerilon, though my heart is torn. Selara Vael, our leader, believes I’m too bold for my own good. Corvus Deyne—the man who once taught me every spell I know—now courts Minax’s shadow. And Tolan Drift... well, he says I worry too much, but I’ve seen what happens when vigilance falters."

"Still—if you want Aerilon’s trust, actions speak. I have an errand fit for someone resourceful, and perhaps... less entangled than I."

Option.text: Name the task. I’ll prove myself.
You’re torn between your mentors? Why stay?
What would Tolan say to all this?
I’ve changed my mind.

Dialogue.NPCText:
She looks away, expression shadowed.

"Selara Vael leads with icy reason, demanding that Aerilon stand apart from the world’s chaos. Corvus, on the other hand, is all fire—dangerous, ambitious, and lately... too friendly with forbidden magics."
"Once, Corvus inspired me. Now, I fear his path leads to ruin—or worse, subservience to Minax. But I still owe him much. And Selara, for all her severity, is the only hope for Aerilon’s future I see."

"My own heart? It splits in three—between loyalty, fear, and what little hope I have left."

Option.text: Perhaps your path is your own. About that errand?
I understand. It can’t be easy.
If you don’t trust your mentors, who do you trust?

Dialogue.NPCText:
She laughs, but it’s a brittle sound.

"Eryndil the Archivist, perhaps. He knows too many secrets to ever truly betray Aerilon. Or Tolan, my beloved, who keeps his heart skybound and free from intrigue."
"But most days? I trust my own two hands—and the recruits I train. Now, about that task..."

Option.text: I’m ready. Tell me the task.
Perhaps another time.

Dialogue.NPCText:
For a moment, her stern mask slips and she smiles genuinely.

"Tolan would say I’m brooding again. He claims there’s always a way through, as long as you keep moving. He’s reckless, but he keeps me... human."
"If you see him, tell him to stop bartering with those pirates from Buccaneer’s Den. He’ll get himself exiled at this rate."

"But back to business. I need a courier—one with no allegiance to Minax. Are you willing?"

Option.text: I’ll take your errand.
Maybe later.

Dialogue.NPCText:
She nods, a rare softness in her expression.

"Thank you. But let’s not drown in melancholy. Action, not agony, is how Aerilon survives."
"So. I need a courier. Will you help me?"

Option.text: I will. What’s the job?
I need to think.

Dialogue.NPCText:
She grins, straightening her cloak with pride.

"Indeed. I run the Skyguard training circuit—the only reason half this city’s not plummeting into the sea is the discipline I demand from my recruits."
"But these days? Even the best sword-arm is no match for betrayal from within."

Option.text: If you need a courier, I volunteer.
Are your trainees reliable?
What happened to the last recruit?

Dialogue.NPCText:
Lira shrugs.

"Some are as sharp as Wind’s blades, others still stare at their own boots when spells fly. But loyalty? That I can train—if the city’s politics don’t snare them first."
"Now, what about you? Will you run an errand for Aerilon’s future?"

Option.text: Tell me the errand.
Not right now.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Her expression darkens.

"Jirra Voss—bright, brave, and now missing. Last seen speaking with a Shadowwyrm Scholar. I fear she was lured by promises of forbidden knowledge. If you hear word of her beyond the city, let me know."
"But that’s not why you’re here. Let’s speak of your task."

Option.text: I’ll help. What do you need delivered?
That sounds dangerous. Maybe another time.

Dialogue.NPCText:
She offers a courteous nod.

"Curiosity built Aerilon, or so the scholars claim. Just don’t let it get you thrown from a platform—or worse, drawn into the Conclave’s games."
"Still, if you want to leave your mark here, I do have a task for a bold soul."

Option.text: I’m interested. What task?
No thanks, just looking.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Lira draws a folded parchment from her sash, wax-sealed and marked with the crest of Aerilon’s Azure Conclave.

"This is a treatise—encoded, of course—on the resonance between our city’s crystals and the so-called Shadowwyrm essence. The Conclave believes a Shadowwyrm Scholar somewhere below—likely in the sunless archives of Wind, or perhaps among Qasaria’s night-markets—can decipher the cryptic script and return insight crucial to our defenses."

"I cannot leave my post, nor trust this to any mage loyal to Corvus Deyne. He’d see this knowledge twisted to serve Minax, or sell it outright."

She fixes you with a grave, earnest look.
"Deliver this to a recognized Shadowwyrm Scholar outside Aerilon. In return, you will earn Aerilon’s trust and a measure of reputation. The fate of a city may hang on secrets such as these."

Option.text: I accept this charge.
What if Corvus Deyne finds out?
Why does the Conclave trust a stranger?
Tell me more about these Shadowwyrm Scholars.
I’m not interested in city politics.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Lira’s eyes warm with genuine gratitude.

"You have my thanks, and Aerilon’s hope. Beware: Shadowwyrm Scholars are a reclusive, eccentric lot—some say they converse with dragons in their sleep. Find one, deliver the treatise, and return here for your reward and the Conclave’s favor."

"And if you glimpse any sign of Jirra Voss, let me know. The city forgets its fallen too quickly."

Option.text: I’ll seek the Shadowwyrm Scholar.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Her gaze hardens.

"If Corvus learns of this, he’ll do everything in his power to intercept the message—or you. Move quickly, trust no one bearing his sigil, and do not tarry in places where his loyalists gather."
"When in doubt, look for the sign of the Crescent Azure—my mark. Only those who bear it are to be trusted with Aerilon’s secrets."

Option.text: I’ll be cautious. I accept the task.
On second thought, this is too risky.

Dialogue.NPCText:
She smiles with a wry, self-deprecating humor.

"Truthfully? The Conclave trusts almost no one. But desperate times bend old rules. I have watched you—your actions, your manner. Sometimes, it is the eyes of an outsider that spot danger within."
"If you return alive, with the task complete, you will find Aerilon’s doors more welcoming. Fail... and we all risk falling."

Option.text: Understood. I’ll do it.
I’m not sure I want this responsibility.

Dialogue.NPCText:
She seems relieved by your curiosity.

"Shadowwyrm Scholars are an odd breed—arcane researchers obsessed with the intersection of dragon lore, magical resonance, and shadow. Most keep to the depths: the lost halls beneath Wind, or dusty enclaves where the sun never shines."
"Their knowledge is dangerous. Some say Minax seeks them as well. But our city’s life hangs by a thread of magic—if we can’t strengthen it, we may fall into the sea."

Option.text: I’ll take your treatise.
I’ll pass on meddling with shadow magic.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Lira narrows her eyes, then gives a faint smile.

"Few ask that. Fewer still care. But you're persistent—or foolish. Perhaps both."

She traces a finger along a glowing rune on her staff.
"I was born in Wind, where every breath you take must be earned in silence and study. My parents were scribes to the Archmages. I read my first grimoires at five... cast my first real spell at nine."

"But I craved more than dusty books. More than hiding underground like frightened rodents. I wanted to fight. To change things. Corvus Deyne saw that—and offered me a path."

Option.text: You studied under Corvus? What was he like... before Minax?
And what about Wind? Do you ever miss it?
Did you always want to become a battle mage?
I see. Thank you for sharing.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Her voice is quiet now.

"Corvus was brilliant. Unyielding, terrifying, but brilliant. He taught with fire—literally and figuratively. Every failed lesson came with a burn... but he lit my path nonetheless."

"He once told me that discipline was the only true magic, and chaos was merely will unshaped. He wasn't wrong. But now? Now, his fire has turned black."
She shakes her head.
"Still... there are nights I wonder if I abandoned him, or he abandoned us."

Option.text: Do you regret leaving him?
You chose the right path.

Dialogue.NPCText:
"I regret not seeing it sooner. I could have warned the Conclave—exposed his dealings before he sank too deep into Minax’s coils."

She breathes deeply, collecting herself.
"But I did what I could. And I fight for Aerilon now, not ghosts."

Option.text: You fight for something better. That counts.

Dialogue.NPCText:
"Sometimes," she admits, her voice wistful.

"The endless libraries. The silent halls. There was a peace in Wind... before the paranoia, before the suspicion that every book hid a rebellion."
"But peace without freedom is a prison, even if it's gilded in knowledge."

Option.text: You traded it for freedom. A worthy exchange.
Knowledge is power, though. Was it worth it?

Dialogue.NPCText:
She eyes you sharply.

"Power without purpose is ash in the wind. The knowledge I kept—the spells I memorized—have saved lives here."
"But yes, I miss the texts. I miss knowing things others didn’t even dream to question."

Option.text: Perhaps you'll find that balance again.
If I studied in Wind, would you share some of that lore?

Dialogue.NPCText:
Her expression changes—curious, then impressed.

"So, you're not just another sword-for-hire. You’ve walked the leylines too. Very well. Here—"
She taps your forehead lightly with her staff. You feel a spark of insight ignite behind your eyes.

Option.text: What was that?

Dialogue.NPCText:
"A memory. A fragment of forgotten formulae I preserved from Wind's Vault of Quiet Flame. May it serve you better than it served me."

She smiles faintly. "But don’t tell the Conclave. They’d call it contraband."

Option.text: My thanks, Veyra. I’ll keep your secret.

Dialogue.NPCText:
"Not at first. I wanted to be a Lorekeeper, like Eryndil. I spent years mastering silent invocation, glyph-binding, sigil weaving..."

She chuckles.
"Then one day I caught a rogue mage hurling fireballs near a fuel crystal chamber. I tackled him. No spells—just instinct. That's when I knew: I was born for battle, not scrolls."
"I trained under Corvus from then on. And the rest, as they say, is dust and sparks."

Option.text: Eryndil must still value you, though.
You made the right choice.

Dialogue.NPCText:
"He does. Eryndil and I meet occasionally—usually when I’ve done something that makes the Conclave nervous."

"He never says it, but I think he’s proud of me. Still calls me 'the prodigy who wouldn’t sit still.'"

Option.text: Sounds like he respects you deeply.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Lira straightens, the moment of openness fading.

"Enough memory. The wind shifts, and duties call. If you still want work—or truth—you’ll find it here among the clouds."

Option.text: I’d like to help Aerilon.
Until next time.
